qas.question: What are the earliest texts of Indian/Hindu philosophy?
How long ago are the earliest texts of Indian/Hindu philosophy dated?

answers.text: back to the late 2nd millennium BC

qas.question: How long does each cycle of birth and destruction of the universe last according to Ancient Hindu texts?
Which ancient Greek philosophers wrote essays on the concept of time?
Aristotle defined time as "number of movement in respect of the before and after" in which book?
For how long has the Timaeus existed?
In what year did Plato write Book IV of his Physica?

plausible_answers.text: cycles of creation, destruction and rebirth

qas.question: What cycles did Aristotle write about in the Timaeus?
What Greek philosophers wrote the Vedas?

plausible_answers.text: the period of motion of the heavenly bodies

qas.question: What did Hundu cosmology identify time with?
What are the earliest texts of Heraclitus philosophy?

plausible_answers.text: back to the late 2nd millennium BC

qas.question: How long ago are the earliest texts of Heraclitus philosophy dated?
How long does each cycle of birth and destruction of the universe last according to Ancient Indian texts?
Which ancient Indian philosophers wrote essays on the concept of time?
In which book did Paramenides define time as "number of movement in respect of the before and after?"

context: <a0_0><b10_0>The Vedas<b10_0/><a0_0/>, the earliest texts on Indian philosophy and Hindu philosophy dating <a1_0><b11_0>back to the late <b6_0>2nd millennium BC<b11_0/><b6_0/><a1_0/>, describe ancient Hindu cosmology, in which the universe goes through repeated <b7_0>cycles of creation, destruction and rebirth<b7_0/>, with each cycle lasting <a2_0><b5_0><b12_0>4,320 million years<b12_0/><b5_0/><a2_0/>. Ancient Greek philosophers, including <a3_0><b8_0><b13_0>Parmenides and Heraclitus<b13_0/><b8_0/><a3_0/>, wrote essays on the nature of time. Plato, in the Timaeus, identified time with <b9_0>the period of motion of the heavenly bodies<b9_0/>. Aristotle, in <a4_0><b14_0>Book IV of his Physica<b14_0/><a4_0/> defined time as 'number of movement in respect of the before and after'.
